Fig. 1 (A) Pyrolysis - reforming setup and (B) composition of pyrolysis gas used for reforming. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Characterization of fresh reforming catalysts: (A) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, (B) XRD patterns, (C) TPR profiles and (D) Ni 2p3/2 XPS core spectra. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (A) Pressure at the outlet of the reforming reactor, and (B) TPO profiles of the catalyst samples after 2 h reforming at S/C = 2, 5 and 8 (catalyst: Ni/Al2O3). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Characteristics of gas after reforming at S/C = 2, 5 and 8: (A) CH4 removal efficiency, (B) C2-C5 removal efficiency, (C) H2 evolution and (D) CO/CO2 selectivity (catalyst: Ni/Al2O3). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Characteristics of gas produced by steam reforming at S/C = 5 over different catalysts: (A) CH4 removal efficiency, (B) C2 – C5 removal efficiency, (C) H2 mass flow, and (D) CO/CO2 molar ratio. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TPO profiles of the catalysts: (A) Ni/Char after 0, 2 and 14 h of reforming, and (B) Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC after 2 and 14 h of reforming. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM-EDS mapping of catalysts after 14 h reforming: (A) Ni/Al2O3, (B) Ni/Char and (C) Ni/FCC. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Raman spectra of spent catalysts (A) after 2 h and (B) 14 h reforming. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (A) N2 adsorption – desorption isotherms and (B) XRD profiles of catalysts after 2 and 14 h reforming. Fig. 9 Table 1 Properties of the pelletized pine sawdust a . Table 1 C(wt%, d.b.) Residues and Resource Reclamation Centre (R3C), Nanyang Environment and Water Research Institute, Nanyang Technological University 637141 Singapore The potential replaceability of a Ni catalyst supported on commercial α-Al2O3 (Ni/Al2O3) by Ni on biomass-derived char (Ni/Char), and Ni on spent fluid catalytic cracking catalyst (Ni/FCC) for steam reforming of biomass pyrolysis gas was investigated (14 h at 850°C, steam/carbon ratio = 5). The catalysts reformed 60–80 % of C2-C5 hydrocarbons, producing 2.7–4.1 mg min−1 of H2. The reforming activity of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC was higher compared to Ni/Char, indicating the beneficial role of metal oxide supports. The use of Al2O3 and FCC resulted in a lower thermo-oxidative stability of coke formed on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC compared to Ni/Char. Furthermore, the deposited Ni showed higher stability towards oxidation by steam into NiO in case of Al2O3 and FCC compared to char. According to reforming activity, H2 production rate, coking, and Ni oxidation of the catalysts, FCC has better prospects as an alternative support in a reforming catalyst than char. Graphical Abstract Keywords Alumina Catalytic steam reforming Biomass pyrolysis gas Char Spent FCC catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With global efforts towards carbon neutrality, biomass pyrolysis has become increasingly popular process for its wide range of industrially applicable products, such as char, bio-oil, and syngas [1]. Char is widely known for its porous properties and surface functional groups [2], making it a common material to synthesise adsorbents or catalysts, while bio-oil is a complex mixture of large groups organic compounds that was found to have several applications as fuel substitutes or chemical synthesis [3]. On the other hand, non-condensable pyrolysis gases, consisting of inorganic gases and some light hydrocarbons (C2-C5), form another important component of pyrolysis products. Non-condensable pyrolysis gases contain low calorific values due to higher N2 and CO2 composition and requires additional processes to improve the gas quality and increase proportion of H2 and CO [4]. By means of reactions such as the water-gas shift, char gasification, catalytic reforming etc., hydrogen enriched syngas could be produced [5]. Catalytic steam reforming is a promising route for converting biomass and waste streams into renewable syngas. Among the main challenges of technology implementation are complexity of biomass feed composition [6], catalyst selection, and process conditions which vary depending on the hydrocarbon gas composition. A study [5] reported varying hydrogen yield from pyrolysis-reforming reaction of different agricultural biomass feedstocks (rice husk, coconut shell, wheat straw, and cotton stalks etc.), using Ni-based supported catalyst, and concluded that the type of feedstock affects the yield of different product gases. Specifically, higher lignin content increased H2 yield due to decomposition of methoxyl functional groups. Higher cellulose/hemicellulose content increased CO and CO2 yields due to higher amount of ether (C-O) and carbonyl (CO) functional groups in the feedstock. Another process parameter investigated is steam to carbon ratio (S/C). Studies show that increasing S/C ratio up to 6 could result in an increase in hydrogen yield to 80 % and reduced deposition of coke on the catalyst surface [7,8]. However, an excess of steam (S/C > 6) could also lead to a decrease in yield of CO due to inhibition of water-gas shift reaction [9], leading to a plateau of H2 yield [10]. The higher S/C is also associated with higher energy consumption for steam generation and lowered reforming temperature, resulting from energy adsorption by steam [9,11]. Type of active metal, presence of catalyst promoters, and selection of catalyst support material could also result in different reforming yields. Nickel is commonly used as the active metal component due to its high catalytic activity and comparatively low cost to noble metals such at Pt or Pd [12]. Multiple studies have attempted to enhance the activity and stability of nickel by modifying the catalyst composition through incorporating metallic promoters (e.g. Ce and La) [11,13], and/or secondary metals (e.g., Cr, Fe and Co) [14]. La2O3 promoted Ni/α-Al2O3 catalyst for steam reforming of bio-oil were reported to have achieved increased resistance to catalyst deactivation by sintering due to higher water adsorption capacity, inhibiting coke-forming precursors [15]. Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts that were used in reforming of biogas also showed higher product gas yield owing to higher BET surface area and more distributed active sites [16]. The support material could influence catalyst activity by means of promoting active metal dispersion [17,18], as well as improving metal – support interaction that reduces catalyst sintering [19]. Choices of support material that are being tested in laboratories vary widely, involving the use numerous metal oxides [20–22] instead of conventional alumina supports. Recent global trends to reduce waste led to the increased interest towards upcycling of waste materials as potential catalyst supports. Steam reforming of pyrolysis gas produced from wheat straw was conducted using materials from spent LiCoO2 batteries as catalysts, achieving 28.3 mmolH2 g−1 biomass production [23]. Municipal solid waste gasification slag was utilized as a support in a Ni-based catalyst for naphthalene steam reforming, demonstrating high reforming efficiency during 5 h tests due to the large number of highly dispersed nickel active sites [24]. Char supported catalysts were also investigated and showed satisfactory catalytic activity, producing syngas up to 109 mmolsyngas g−1 biomass for 2 h of reforming [25]. In another study, carbon supported ruthenium catalysts used in glycerol steam reforming showed varying efficiencies and stabilities reportedly due to differences in degree of graphitisation of the carbon support [26]. The usage of char as a support in reforming catalysts was reported in several other studies have also shown that on top of porosity, the surface functional groups, crystallinity of carbon, and presence of certain metallic impurities contributes significantly to improving catalytic activity and stability [27–29]. The interest to this material is associated with its abundance and low cost in comparison to alumina, coupled with high porosity and the presence of ash components that can intensify reforming reactions. Fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) catalysts are generally used for hydrocarbon cracking in petroleum refinery processes, but some studies have suggested the use of the spent FCC catalysts for pyrolysis/gasification reactions [30–32] and found promising results of increased hydrocarbon conversion efficiencies and syngas yield (H2 yield increased by 84 %, CO yield increased by 25 %) after 0.5 h of CO2 – assisted gasification and pyrolysis [30]. The interest towards recycling of spent FCC catalysts is associated with large quantities of these materials that are being outputs of petroleum refining industry. Annually, the spent FCC catalysts generated in the world ranges about 400,000–966,000 tonnes [33,34] and due to precipitation of heavy metals, the spent FCC catalysts are classified as hazardous waste [34]. Although the use of char and spent FCC supports has shown promising results in the field of catalytic steam reforming, there are insufficient studies about stability of reforming catalysts utilizing these supports over time compared to widely used alumina. Understanding long-term stability of catalyst (several hours) can provide valuable information in catalyst design and justify the replacement of alumina with alternative materials. In many studies, the loss of catalytic activity is attributable to coking [35]. Coke deposition on catalysts is primarily formed due to dehydrogenation of the adsorbed hydrocarbons and polycondensation on the active metal surface [36,37] and support, leading to the loss of catalytic activity as the active sites are blocked. In-line steam reforming of biomass pyrolysis volatiles observed exponential deactivation of Ca doped Ni/Al2O3 catalyst after 50 min on stream (H2 yield decreases from 80 % to 50 %), which was attributed to gradual loss of active metal by coke encapsulation in the first 50 min, and consequently accelerated coke deposition by unreformed thermally decomposed oxygenated volatiles [38]. Steam reforming of benzene for syngas production, over Ni based catalyst using sludge and peat char as supports was reported in [39]. A 10 % decline in syngas yield due to carbon deposition (20 wt%) after 5.5 h was observed. One notable study explored the use of spent FCC as a catalyst for attenuating biomass pyrolysis gas through partial conversion of bio-oil components into non-condensable gas prior to steam reforming [40]. The pre-reforming catalyst achieved a low coke deposition rate (0.98 mgcoke g−1 cat g−1 biomass) which was then attributed to poor suitability of the material as a guard catalyst to prevent coking of downstream steam reforming Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The authors suggested due to the acidic nature of spent FCC, polymerization reactions involving in-stream bio-oil oxygenated compounds led to an increase in phenolic hydrocarbon fractions, producing coke with a more aromatic structure. Several studies also attributed coke deposition to condensation of heavy hydrocarbons, resulting in formation of polyaromatic coke on the acidic surface [41–44]. Although biomass pyrolysis-induced coke deposits on FCCs were not widely studied, some researchers suggest that pore structure (sizes of micropores) of the catalyst [45] and the type of feed gas [46] could also influence degree of condensation of coke precursors. These results present opportunities to further investigate the material’s low coke deposition properties in the application as a support material for steam reforming catalyst. The study also pointed out catechol fractions from bio-oil, as the cause of coking in the downstream reforming catalyst [40], however, it is unclear whether the increase in non-condensable pyrolysis gas fractions contributed to the downstream catalyst coke deactivation. El-Rub et al. reviewed on the use of several catalysts including spent FCC and char, and also reported rapid deactivation of FCC catalyst by coke from tar components in steam reforming of biomass pyrolysis gas [47], while a kinetic model by Arregi et al. suggests that oxygenated compounds in bio-oil were responsible for amorphous coke formation over Ni/Al2O3 reforming catalysts [48]. Most studies on steam reforming of pyrolysis volatiles conclude that the bulk of coke deposited is due to heavy hydrocarbons but neglect the influence of light hydrocarbons as a contributor to coke formation. Angeli et al. highlighted coke inducing effects of light alkanes on a Ni-based catalyst in steam reforming of methane, forming filamentous carbon [49]. There is limited understanding about types of coke deposited on catalysts when non-condensable pyrolysis gas is used for steam reforming. Furthermore, there is a lack of comparative studies on catalysts supported by conventional alumina and alternative materials, such as char and spent FCC, under similar operation conditions. This gap makes it difficult to identify the differences in deactivation behavior and catalytic activity. Hence, char and spent FCC were used as supports for Ni-based steam reforming catalysts in the reforming of pyrolysis gas from wood biomass (pine sawdust pellets), a common type of feedstock used in commercial biochar production. The objective was to investigate the potential replaceability of alumina with these low-cost support materials. The reforming activity, hydrogen production and coking of the prepared Ni catalysts was investigated and compared with Ni supported on alumina. The catalyst performance towards decomposition of hydrocarbon compounds and structural changes were characterized after 2 and 14 h of reforming, providing important insights about evolution of activity and coke deposits of these materials during renewable syngas generation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Pyrolysis gas preparation and reforming Pyrolysis gas for reforming tests was obtained from pelletized pine sawdust. The properties of feedstock are provided in Table 1. The feedstock was pyrolyzed at 600 °C (50 mL min−1 N2 flow) in a vertical stainless steel reactor ( Fig. 1A) with a feeding rate of 10 ± 0.5 g every 10 min. In a typical run, the feeding of feedstock continued for approximately 5 h. The produced liquid volatile products (bio-oil) were condensed in an empty trap submerged in an ice bath, while the remaining non-condensable pyrolysis gas was collected and stored in a 100 L gas sampling bag (Hedetech) for the subsequent steam reforming. Pyrolysis experiments yielded 21 wt% char, 39.5 wt% bio-oil, and 39.5 wt% non-condensable pyrolysis gas (calculated by difference). Studies reported high operational temperature to be desirable to minimise loss of catalytic activity by feed impurities [50,51], hence α-Al2O3, a thermally stable support with high H2 selectivity [52], was selected. For each reforming experiment, 0.24 g of a catalyst was loaded into a fixed bed quartz reactor with a quartz frit having pores of 50 – 90 µm, heated in 50 mL min−1 N2 at 15 °C min−1 to 850 °C and reduced at this temperature in a mixture of 10 mL min−1 H2 and 40 mL min−1 N2 for 30 min. After the reduction, pyrolysis gas was supplied into the reactor using an air sampler (QC-1B, Beijing KeAn pte ltd), while steam was generated by evaporation of deionized water at 150 °C, injected with a syringe pump (Fusion 200, Chemyx). The flow of dry pyrolysis gas was fixed at 100 mL min−1. Steam input was calculated based on the number of moles of organic C in the pyrolysis gas stream to obtain steam to carbon ratios (S/C) of 2, 5 and 8. The corresponding wet flows of gas were 161, 253 and 344 mL min−1, respectively. These S/C ratios were evaluated due to their significance in the industry, S/C ratio of 2–3 has been well established in methane steam reforming reactions [18], whereas S/C ratio used for reforming of tar and pyrolysis gas ranges between 3 and 10 [53]. The high temperature and excess steam introduced aims to minimise catalyst deactivation by coke deposition [54], sulfur poisoning [55] and also favors the shift in chemical equilibrium promoting higher conversion efficiencies of organic compounds [56,57]. The reforming experiments were continued 14 h with an overnight break after 7 h. During the break, pyrolysis gas and steam were replaced with N2 and the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The next day, the reactor was re-heated to 850 °C, and the reforming experiments proceeded for another 7 h. Gas samples were collected at 30 min intervals and analysed by a gas chromatograph outfitted with two thermal conductivity and one flame ionization detectors (Agilent 7890B) calibrated for H2, N2, O2, CO, CO2, CH4, and specific C2 – C5 hydrocarbons (see Table S1 for a list of compounds). The obtained pyrolysis gas was composed of H2 (9.5 vol%), CO (35.0 vol%), CO2 (18.6 vol%), CH4 (12.4 vol%), C2-C5 gases (5.0 vol%) and N2 (balance) (Fig. 1B). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis Three 10 wt% Ni catalysts were synthesized by wet co-impregnation of nickel and alumina precursors onto 3 supports, namely α-Al2O3 (SA52238, Saint-Gobain), pyrolysis char from pine sawdust pellets (see preparation in Section 2.1), and spent fluid cracking catalyst (FCC, obtained from a refinery plant). Commercial α-Al2O3 (100–315 µm) and spent FCC catalyst (<100 µm) were used as received, while pyrolysis char was crushed to 100 – 315 µm size. Approximately 4.95 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) and 6.24 g of aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water. The purpose of Al precursor was to improve Ni dispersion on the support surface at high calcination temperature, shown in a study where the formation of nickel aluminate layer increases Ni dispersion [58] and suppresses sintering [59]. The support material (7.88 g) was added into the solution. The mixture was shaken and sonicated for 30 min before solvent evaporation using a rotary evaporator (Hei-Vap Precision, Heidolph Instruments). The resulting material was dried overnight in an oven at 105 °C before calcination under air (in case of α-Al2O3 and spent FCC catalyst) or N2 (in case of char) at 850 °C for 5 h (heating rate of 5 °C min−1), and lastly, sieved to obtain particle sizes between 100 – 315 µm. The prepared catalysts were denoted as Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Char and Ni/FCC. 2.3 Sample characterization Surface morphology and composition of fresh and spent catalysts were analysed using field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JEOL JSM-7600F), transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-1400Plus) and X-ray diffraction spectroscopy with a Cu-Kα radiation source (XRD, Bruker AXS D8 Advance). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using Kratos AXIS Supra, and binding energies were charge corrected against Al 2p 74.7 eV [60–62]. Peaks were deconvoluted and fitted on Shirley background coupled with Lorentzian-Asymmetric function using CASA XPS software. Total pore volume, Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area were determined from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms measured at −196 °C (Quantachrome Autosorb-1 Analyser). Nickel content in catalysts was analysed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Perkin Elmer Optima 8300): 0.1 – 0.5 g of catalysts were digested in 6 mL HNO3 (60 %), 2 mL HCl (37 %), 1 mL H2O2 (30 %), and 1 mL HF (50 %) using microwave assisted digestion (Multiwave 5000, Anton Paar) at 180 °C for 20 min. The reducibility of synthesized catalysts were determined by temperature programmed reduction (TPR): approximately 25 mg of catalyst was pretreated in 50 mL min−1 N2 at 150 °C for 30 min before reduction in 50 mL min−1 H2 – Ar atmosphere (5 vol% H2) from 30 to 950 °C (heating rate 5 °C min−1). Coke deposition after reforming was characterized by ultimate analysis (Vario EL cube, Elementar) and temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) in a thermogravimetry apparatus using a mixture of air and N2 (20 vol% O2) at 120 mL min−1 flow, heating rate 20 °C min−1 (STA 449 F5 Jupiter, NETZSCH). Molar and mass flows of individual gas components were calculated using gas chromatography data: (1) M a f = 1 22.4 * v total ( p ) * C N 2 p C N 2 f * C x ( f ) (2) M a p = 1 22.4 * v N 2 p C N 2 p * C x ( p ) Where Ma(f) and Ma(p) are the molar flow rates (mmol min−1) of feed and product gases, CN2(f), CN2(p), Cx(f) and Cx(p) are the volumetric composition (vol%) of N2 and compounds of interest(x), in feed(f) and product(p) gases, respectively, v total ( p ) and v N 2 ( p ) are the flow rates (mL min−1) of product gas and N2, respectively. The cumulative content of C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds was calculated by the summation of data for each measured hydrocarbon compound with carbon atoms between 2 and 5. Removal efficiencies of CH4 and C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds were calculated as the molar difference between hydrocarbon gas composition in the feed and product gases: (3) CH 4 removal efficiency ( % ) = X CH 4 ( f ) − Y CH 4 ( p ) X CH 4 ( f ) × 100 % (4) C 2 − C 5 removal efficiency ( % ) = X C 2 − C 5 ( f ) − Y C 2 − C 5 ( p ) X C 2 − C 5 ( f ) × 100 % where X(f) and Y(p) represent the molar concentrations of hydrocarbon compounds in feed and product gases, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of reforming catalysts Fig. 2A shows N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the fresh catalysts. N2 uptake at relative pressure P/P0 < 0.1 is attributable to adsorption in micropores (pore diameters < 2 nm) and at P/P0 of 0.1–0.96 in mesopores (pore diameters of 2–50 nm) [63]). Owing to the negligible N2 uptake at P/P0 < 0.1 and negligible hysteresis, the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst can be characterized as a mesoporous solid with N2 adsorption predominantly unrestricted by pores. Adsorption on Ni/FCC and Ni/Char is more complex as the catalysts contain a mixture of micro- and mesopores. The isotherms have a distinct hysteresis loop at P/P0 > 0.4 due to capillary condensation in pores. According to the higher N2 uptake at P/P0 < 0.1, Ni/Char has the larger microporous volume in comparison to the other two catalysts. The corresponding BJH pore size distributions are provided in Fig. S1. The sizes of mesopores in Ni/Al2O3 are widely distributed in a range between 5 and 30 nm, while in Ni/FCC the distribution is narrower, between 5 and 20 nm. Table 2 summarizes the BET specific surface areas and total pore volumes calculated from the isotherms. Ni/Char has the highest specific surface area (212 m2 g−1), followed by Ni/FCC and Ni/Al2O3 (83 and 24 m2 g−1 respectively). The total pore volume of the catalysts follows the same order. Bulk density of Ni/Char (0.49 g mL−1) was the lowest among the catalysts. ICP-OES analysis of synthesized catalysts verified the actual nickel content was close to 10 wt% (10.7, 10.5 and 10.2 wt% Ni in Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Char and Ni/FCC, respectively). Other metal impurities are also shown in Table 2. FESEM and TEM – EDS (Fig. S2 and Fig. S3) illustrated good dispersion of nickel over the support surfaces. XRD patterns of the fresh reduced (Fig. 2B) and unreduced (Fig. S4A) catalysts show the presence of crystalline phases of corresponding supports, namely, α-Al2O3 (PDF #04–010–6477) in Ni/Al2O3, partially crystallized graphitic carbon (PDF #04–015–2407 & PDF #04–016–6288) in Ni/Char, and a plurality of peaks from Zeolite Y phase in Ni/FCC [64,65] (Fig. 2B). Crystalline phases of NiO (PDF #04–006–6925) were formed in Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC catalysts (Fig. S4A) upon calcination in air. Additionally, these unreduced catalysts contained traces of NiAl2O4 spinel (PDF #00–010–0339), formed due to sintering of nickel and aluminum oxides during the synthesis (NiO + Al2O3 → NiAl2O4) (Fig. S4A). The reduction of these Ni species by H2 primarily forms crystalline metallic Ni (PDF #04–016–6268) (Fig. 2B). On the contrary, the XRD patterns for reduced and unreduced Ni/Char indicates that metallic Ni (PDF #04–016–6268) was observed in prior to H2 reduction (Fig. S4A), suggesting the bulk reduction of nickel precursor were by carbon (Ni2+ + 2e- → Ni°) during calcination in N2, which is consistent with other studies [66,67], and H2 reduction played a minimal role in the formation of metallic Ni. Due to the carbon reduction of nickel, this catalyst did not contain NiAl2O4 phase unlike the other two unreduced catalysts. There were no XRD peaks solely attributable to the added alumina precursor other than NiAl2O4 in Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC (Fig. S4A), despite the detection of Al by ICP-OES, suggesting that added Al2O3 that did not react with NiO during calcination had mainly non-crystalline structure. The presence of Al2O3 is supported by ICP-OES as crystalline alumina support (α-Al2O3) was resistant to the acid dissolution [68], and therefore did not contribute to the detectable alumina content. The detectable (non-crystalline) alumina content is comparable with the theoretical precursor load (approx. 4.5 ± 0.5 wt%). XPS was used to investigate the state of Ni on the surface of the reforming catalysts. Ni 2p3/2 XPS core spectra of unreduced catalysts (Fig. S4B) showed a main peak with binding energies of 855.8 – 856.3 eV, corresponding to Ni2+ in NiO [69]. Additionally, the spectra of unreduced Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC contain minor peaks with binding energies of 857.5 eV and 857.6 eV, respectively, ascribed to Ni2+ in NiAl2O4 [70]. The Ni 2p3/2 XPS core spectra shown in Fig. 2D represents the catalysts after H2 reduction. Ni2+ peak previously associated to NiAl2O4 in Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC could not be observed, while a distinctive peak with binding energies 852.5 – 852.6 eV was detected and is associated to Ni0. The main peak with binding energies of 855.9 – 856.2 eV in the reduced catalysts (including Ni/Char), likewise corresponds to Ni2+ in NiO [69]. However, this discrepancy from XRD data in the XPS spectrum in terms of NiO, could be justified by the formation of a thin layer of NiO on the surface of Ni0 due to exposure to air during sample handling and storage. [71], while subsequent spectra for Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Char and Ni/FCC are consistent with the crystalline phases from XRD data (Fig. 2B), showing presence of Ni0 species (with peak binding energies of 852.5 – 852.6) on the catalyst surface prior to reforming. The reducibility of Ni species in the fresh catalysts was studied by H2 – TPR (Fig. 2C) and 0.98 mmol g−1, 0.90 mmol g−1 and 2.0 mmol g−1 of H2 were consumed for the reduction of Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Char, and Ni/FCC catalysts respectively. Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC had strong reduction peaks between 400 and 820 °C. The reduction at low temperatures (i.e. 400–600 °C) for Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC respectively, could be ascribed to NiO species; (1) bulk NiO reduced at lower temperature peaks (437 °C and 491 °C) and (2) NiO interacting with supports reduced at higher temperature (488 °C and 591 °C) [72,73]). The higher temperature reduction peak (768 °C in Ni/Al2O3 and 775 °C in Ni/FCC) is associated with the reduction of Ni2+ in NiAl2O4 lattice [74], a peak observed in the XRD (PDF #00–010–0339) and XPS of the unreduced catalyst (Fig. S4). The H2 – TPR profile of Ni/Char showed consumption of H2 over a temperature range between 150 and 800 °C with the maximum intensity at 562 °C. The broad consumption profile was suggested to be due to reduction of amorphous carbon into methane [75], while the peak at 562 °C was associated with methanation of CO2 [76]. There were no distinct peaks in Ni/Char attributable to the reduction of NiO and NiAl2O4 observed in the other two catalysts. 3.2 Effect of S/C ratio on reforming The influence of S/C ratio on the reforming of pyrolysis gas was studied using the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. S/C ratios of 2, 5, and 8 were investigated over 2 h catalytic steam reforming ( Fig. 3A). The reactor pressure remained constant for S/C = 5 and 8 (approx. 14.6 – 14.7 psia). However, an increase in the reactor pressure was observed for S/C = 2 after 1 h of reforming owing to the excessive coking on the surface of the catalyst particles, which restricted the gas flow through the catalyst bed. This was caused by the lack of sufficient amount of water to reform hydrocarbon compounds and gasify formed carbon deposits. The presence of coke was confirmed by TPO of the catalyst samples after reforming. TG and DTG curves of all samples showed mass loss starting at temperature above 500 °C and peaking at approx. 710 °C (Fig. 3B). The oxidation below 500 °C is typically ascribed to amorphous forms of carbon, while the oxidation at higher temperatures is attributed to carbon with higher degree of crystallinity [77]. The largest mass loss (29.9 wt%) was observed for S/C = 2, indicating the largest amount of deposited coke. Whereas S/C = 5 and 8 demonstrated mass losses of 17.3 wt% and 0.18 wt%, respectively. In the following sections, S/C = 5 is used for testing the long term stability of different catalysts as this S/C ratio assured no pressure build up in the catalyst bed. To understand how a S/C ratio can influence the composition of product gas, the gas exiting the reforming reactor was analysed using gas chromatography and the results are shown in Fig. 4. Initially, CH4 removal efficiency was the highest at S/C = 8 but decreased rapidly within the 2 h testing to below 0 %, converging with the values for S/C = 2 and 5 (Fig. 4A). Based on these results, CH4 containing in the pyrolysis gas has high tolerance towards catalytic reforming at the studied conditions. Additionally, the decrease below 0 % indicates that more CH4 exited the reforming reactor compared to the CH4 supplied to the reactor with the biomass-derived pyrolysis gas, suggesting the formation of methane during the reforming process. Similar results were obtained using pyrolysis gas from plastics for steam reforming over a Ni catalyst [78]. An explanation of these results is provided in another study that investigated steam reforming of CH4 mixed with C2H6, C3H8 and n-C4H10 alkanes [79]. The results showed that the presence of hydrocarbon compounds with > 1 carbon atoms could increase methanation rate, due to the higher hydrogen production rate from C2-C4 alkanes and decreasing steam-to-carbon ratio due to such reactions. (5) Methanation: CO + 3H2 ↔ CH4 + H2O Moreover, CH4 methanation increased with the decrease in the CH4 molar fraction in the gas mixture, indicating the higher CH4 formation in mixtures with longer chain hydrocarbon compounds compared to the pure methane stream [79]. According to Fig. 4B, unlike CH4, C2 – C5 hydrocarbon compounds containing in pyrolysis gas, exhibited high removal efficiency of 90 % irrespective of S/C ratio due to higher reactivity of the compounds. In the first 10 min of reaction at S/C = 8, H2 production was higher compared to S/C = 2 and 5 (Fig. 4C). Considering a positive correlation with the higher CH4 conversion rate, this could be related to the higher rate of methane reforming within the first minutes of reaction. Another possible explanation for this phenomenon is initially higher water-gas shift reaction (Eq. 6), as suggested by Fig. 4D, showing lower CO/CO2 ratio in the product gas at S/C = 8, and lower methanation reaction (Eq. 5). Nevertheless, the H2 production rates and CO/CO2 ratio became comparable for all S/C ratios within the 2 h of reforming. (6) Water − gas shift : CO + H 2 O ⇄ C O 2 + H 2 3.3 Effect of supports on reforming activity The reforming experiments were conducted for 14 h to investigate the stability of catalysts prepared using three different supports (S/C = 5). The characteristics of the gas produced, calculated from effluent gas composition (Fig. S5), during the runs are shown in Fig. 5. Regardless of the catalyst, CH4 was not reformed. Instead, it was generated during the process, likely due to methanation as suggested by negative values of the CH4 removal efficiency (–25 %) in Fig. 5A. On the contrary, all three catalysts showed high reforming activity towards C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds within 14 h testing (Fig. 5B). The activity of Ni/Char was slightly lower compared to Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC, likely due to higher degree of Ni oxidation on Ni/Char, resulting in lower amount of active Ni0 (Fig. 9B). Hydrogen evolution in Fig. 5C shows that the production of this gas is higher within the first 1 h of reaction and decreases thereafter for all catalysts. One possible reason for this initial decline in H2 production rate could be due to the deactivation of catalyst through pore blockage by coke deposition, as some active Ni sites become inaccessible [80]. The H2 production by Ni/Char was lower (2.7 mg min−1) compared to Ni/Al2O3 (4.1 mg min−1) and Ni/FCC (3.9 mg min−1). In comparison to some literatures where H2 production ranges between 1.8 and 2.5 mg min−1 for alumina supported catalyst [81], while char supports varies between 0.6 mg min−1 [82] and 1.9 mg min−1 [83,84], the synthesized catalysts exhibited higher H2 production than some of the reported literature, possibly due to the difference in hydrocarbon gas composition, S/C ratio, temperature, and other experimental conditions. Another difference of Ni/Char from the other two catalysts is in the CO/CO2 selectivity (Fig. 5D). CO/CO2 ratio in the beginning of testing was 1.1 and gradually increased to 1.5 during 14 h. On the other hand, the CO/CO2 ratios of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC were initially 1.5 and increased to 1.9 during 14 h. The lower CO/CO2 ratio of Ni/Char could be linked to higher water-gas shift activity [85] and/or lower C2-C5 reforming activity. In previous studies, the higher water-gas shift activity was associated with higher dispersion of Ni on the support due to higher Ni-support interactions [50]. Considering comparable Ni loading on the three catalysts as shown in Table 2, the lower reforming rate over Ni/Char indicates lower Ni activity towards reforming when char was used as a support. Our findings suggest that further improvements in the development of catalysts supported on char would be required to achieve comparable activity with a catalyst prepared from conventional alumina. Notably, based on C2-C5 reforming activity and H2 production by Ni/FCC shown in Fig. 5, spent FCC can be an alternative support for Ni in reforming catalysts. Lower heating values (LHV) calculated from gas composition (Fig. S6 and Table S3) shows the change in compositional contribution to energy content. In pyrolysis gas, LHV was 12.58 ± 0.06 MJ Nm−3, and can be broken down into CO (35.4 %), CH4 (33.1 %), C2-C5 hydrocarbons (25.6 %), and H2 (5.9 %) by contribution. A decrease in LHV of the produced gas after 14 h reforming was observed, with similar LHV values across the 3 catalysts (approx. 10.90 – 10.97 MJ Nm−3). Main contributors to LHV in product gas after 14 h reforming (Table S3) shows a decrease in contribution by C2-C5 hydrocarbons (<10 %), and an increase in contribution by H2 (20 – 30 %), while CO and CH4 contribution remains fairly constant. Notably, Ni/Char has the lowest heating value (10.90 MJ Nm−3), likely due to the decrease in H2 in the reformed gas, which is consistent with the results shown in Fig. 5C. 3.4 Changes in catalyst characteristics during reforming TPO analysis provides information about the stability of carbon in catalysts ( Fig. 6). In Fig. 6A, TPO profiles of Ni/Char are shown. The mass loss increased from 70.2 wt% for the fresh catalyst to 72.5 wt% after 2 h and 81.5 wt% after 14 h of reforming. What is interesting here is the stability of carbon shown in the DTG profiles. The profile of fresh Ni/Char has one peak with a maximum at approx. 625 °C, corresponding to the oxidation of char. While the total mass of carbon barely changes after 2 h of reforming as suggested by the TG curves, the intensity of this oxidation peak in the DTG profile declines and a new peak emerges with a maximum at approx. 760 °C. The oxidation temperature of coke above 600 °C suggests its pyrolytic nature [35]. After 14 h of reforming, the peak at 625 °C disappears and a broad peak in the TPO profile is the one at 760 °C with a shoulder at approx. 700 °C. This shows prominent changes in the structure of the Ni/Char catalysts under reforming conditions. Char support is either being oxidized by H2O and CO2 and replaced with more stable coke by the end of 14 h reforming run. Alternatively, coke that covers char surface, shields it from oxidation, increasing the stability. In case of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC, coking behaviour was different (Fig. 6B). After 2 h or reforming, the coke contents were 21.3 wt% for Ni/Al2O3 and 0.4 wt% for Ni/FCC. After 14 h, these values increased to 32.4 wt% for Ni/Al2O3 and 34.0 wt% for Ni/FCC. It can be implied from these results that coke deposition on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC has different rates, with a coking rate being higher for Ni/Al2O3 at the first 2 h of reforming and declining thereafter. A small amount of carbon in the feed gas (approx. 1.1 wt%, 0.3 wt%, and 0.8 wt%) was converted into coke deposits on the surface of Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Char, Ni/FCC respectively. Based on the shift of the position of peaks towards higher temperatures, coke stability slightly increases with the duration of reforming, which is consistent with [86]. After 14 h, DTG profiles of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC show that the coke stability towards oxidation is comparable for these two catalysts with one oxidation peak having maximum at approx. 720 °C. A comparable coke stability was observed in a study of steam reforming of simulated bio-oil over Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 at 800 °C and S/C = 5, showing the major oxidation peak at 730 °C [87]. On the contrary, coke deposits obtained from reforming a mixture of non-condensable gases and bio-oil Ni/Al2O3 at 800 °C in [88] had lower oxidation temperatures (two peaks at approx. 400 and 550 °C). The discrepancies between coke stabilities in different studies could be related to the differences in experimental conditions. Since in our study, coking of the three catalysts was compared at the same conditions, the results allow to conclude that after 14 h of reforming, stability of coke on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC is lower than that of the coke deposited on Ni/Char. In agreement with TPO data, XPS characterization of the catalysts after reforming suggests accumulation of carbon on the catalyst surfaces ( Table 3). As reforming duration becomes longer, the content of C increases, while the content of other elements decreases (e.g., Ni, O and Al in the three catalysts, Ca in Ni/Char and Si and Fe in Ni/FCC) due to dilution effect and coverage by coke. Although all three catalysts showed high tendency to coke formation between 2 and 14 h of reforming, deposited coke had a minor impact on C2-C5 reforming, H2 production and CO/CO2 selectivity during this period, indicating that Ni activity remained high up to 14 h of the experiments. Surface morphology of the spent catalysts characterized by TEM after 14 h reforming is shown in Fig. 7. Regardless of the type of catalyst support, mixtures of filamentous and non-filamentous forms of coke were found on the catalyst surfaces. This can be seen from TEM images and corresponding EDS maps, showing the location and shape of carbon nanostructures. TEM-EDS mapping for Ni and Al shows colocation of these elements in the spent catalysts. The results suggest that the use of Al salt during synthesis leads to a unique structure of Ni catalyst particles, with active metal phase containing Al atoms. Further studies are required to investigate whether this type of catalyst modification is linked to the ability of catalysts to maintain stable reforming of C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds and high H2 production over prolonged process time. Raman spectroscopy was used to investigate the degree of disorder in the obtained coke deposits. Fig. 8 shows D- and G-bands from carbon at 1340 and 1590 cm−1, corresponding to defective sp3 hybridized and graphitic sp2 hybridized atoms, respectively [89]. The ratio of areas of peaks from D- and G-bands (ID/IG) was used as a measurement of the degree of disorder of coke and was calculated based on five spectra taken from different sample areas. For the three catalysts, the ID/IG ratios were 1.2–1.6 after 2 h and 1.4–1.8 after 14 h of reforming. The only statistically significant change was observed in case of Ni/Char with ID/IG ratio slightly increasing from 1.2 ± 0.2–1.8 ± 0.2, which is probably related to the gradual carbon transformation of char support. The obtained ID/IG ratios suggest high degree of structural defects in coke deposits regardless of the type of support used for catalyst synthesis. Fig. 9A depicts N2 adsorption isotherms of spent catalysts after 2 and 14 h. Compared to adsorption on the fresh catalysts, N2 uptake was lower after 2 h of reforming, which could be due to pore blockage by coke deposits and the lower porosity of coke. All catalysts show N2 uptake mostly occurred at P/P0 > 0.1, corresponding to adsorption in meso- and macropores of the coked catalysts. The corresponding BET specific surface areas were 10, 142, 75 m2 g−1 after 2 h of reforming on Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Char and Ni/FCC (Table S2), decreasing from 24, 212 and 83 m2 g−1 in the fresh catalysts. The largest decrease was observed in Ni/Char. One possible reason is the burn-off of the porous char due to exposure to oxidizing agents (H2O and CO2) at the reforming temperature. Another possible reason is the intense coke deposition in the pores of the char support. Previously, it was shown in another study that when reforming temperature increases, coke deposits tend to accumulate in char pores [90]. After 14 h of reforming, the N2 uptake by Ni/Al2O3 slightly increased causing the increase in BET surface area to 15 m2 g−1, probably due to higher porosity of deposited coke compared to the porosity of the freshly calcined Al2O3 support. On the contrary, the adsorption of N2 and the BET specific surface areas of Ni/Char and Ni/FCC further declined (BET specific surface areas of 74 and 61 m2 g−1, respectively), suggesting lower porosity of deposited coke compared to the porosity of these two supports. Fig. 9B show XRD diffractograms of the catalysts after 2 and 14 h of reforming. Crystalline phase of graphitic carbon (PDF # 04–018–7559) can be observed in the spent catalysts with the XRD peak intensity increasing with longer reforming time relative to the intensities of XRD peaks from other compounds. The XRD peak parameters of coke are different from the parameters of crystalline carbon in char as suggested by different PDF # of reference card. The increase in coke formation observed from XRD at longer reforming time is consistent the with TPO data for the catalysts. Only metallic Ni phase (PDF # 04–016–6268) is identified in Ni/Al2O3, while in Ni/Char and Ni/FCC nickel was partially oxidized into NiO (PDF # 04–006–6925). Oxidation of Ni in the catalysts is attributed to the presence of the excess of steam at S/C = 5. The similar transformation of Ni into NiO during steam reforming was observed in other studies at S/C = 2 [91], S/C = 2.5 [92] and S/C = 3 [93]. Our findings suggest that the three supports have different effect on the stability of Ni towards oxidation. Apart from the support, the extent of Ni oxidation depends on the process duration, increasing at longer reforming time. As shown in Table 4, Ni/Al2O3 has the highest stability towards Ni oxidation (NiO/Ni ratios of 0 after 2 and 14 h of reforming). In Ni/FCC, oxidation was observed only after 14 h (NiO/Ni ratio of 1.6). Ni in Ni/Char was the most susceptible to oxidation by steam. Among the three catalysts, XRD profile of Ni/Char showed the presence of NiO as early as after 2 h of reforming (NiO/Ni ratio of 0.9). After 14 h of reforming, Ni/Char contained the highest amount of NiO as suggested by the lowest NiO/Ni ratio of 0.6. Oxidation of Ni between 2 and 14 h did not seem to cause changes in the reforming activity of CH4 and C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds shown in Fig. 5A and B. Ni oxidation could be related to the slight decrease in H2 production (Fig. 5C) by Ni/FCC and Ni/Char and increase in CO/CO2 ratio by Ni/Char within this period. However, longer testing of catalysts would be required to confirm these observations. 4 Conclusions Biomass-derived char and spent FCC catalyst were tested as supports for Ni-based catalysts in steam reforming of biomass pyrolysis gas (Ni/Char and Ni/FCC). Reforming activity, hydrogen production and coking of Ni catalysts prepared with these abundant supports were compared with those of a Ni on a commercial alumina (Ni/Al2O3). It was observed that S/C = 5 was the sufficient amount of steam for reforming of pyrolysis gas at 850 °C without pressure build up in the catalyst bed due to coking for 14 h. At these reforming conditions, CH4 production increased during reforming of the pyrolysis gas over the three catalysts, suggesting high stability of the molecule and enhanced methanation rate, influenced by gas composition (i.e. low CH4 partial pressure in pyrolysis/reforming gas and high H2 content produced from C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds). All three catalysts demonstrated high reforming activity towards C2-C5 hydrocarbon compounds. The activity of Ni/Char was slightly lower compared to Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC despite higher porosity of char and comparable Ni content in the catalysts, suggesting lower Ni activity towards reforming when char was used as a support. Among the three catalysts, significant changes in the structure of the Ni/Char catalyst were observed during 14 h of reforming. TPO data show that the char support can be either oxidized by H2O and CO2 and replaced with more stable coke by the end of 14 h runs or coke covered char surface to the extent that it changed oxidation behaviour of the composite, increasing its stability. TPO profiles of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC showed comparable oxidation stability of coke after 14 h. The coke stability on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC was lower compared to coke deposited on Ni/Char. However, these deposited coke had a minor impact on C2-C5 reforming, H2 production and CO/CO2 selectivity for the three catalysts. According to the obtained data, the results suggest that further improvements in the development of catalysts supported on char would be required to achieve comparable reforming activity with a catalyst prepared from alumina. Potential avenues for refinement may include physio-chemical activation and functionalization of char surface to enhance the distribution of active metal and improve metal-support interaction. Additionally, investigating various allotropes of carbon as supports could provide insight to different coke deposition phenomenon. On the contrary, similar activities of Ni on Al2/O3 and spent FCC as suggested by C2-C5 reforming activity and H2 production rates, suggest that the spent FCC catalyst can potentially be an alternative support for Ni in reforming catalysts. Additionally, the application of these catalysts could be further extended from fixed to fluidized bed reactor designs, which could enhance conversion efficiency and facilitate the reforming of heavier tar compounds present in biomass pyrolysis volatiles. coredata.dc:description: The potential replaceability of a Ni catalyst supported on commercial α-Al2O3 (Ni/Al2O3) by Ni on biomass-derived char (Ni/Char), and Ni on spent fluid catalytic cracking catalyst (Ni/FCC) for steam reforming of biomass pyrolysis gas was investigated (14 h at 850°C, steam/carbon ratio = 5). The catalysts reformed 60–80 % of C2-C5 hydrocarbons, producing 2.7–4.1 mg min−1 of H2. The reforming activity of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC was higher compared to Ni/Char, indicating the beneficial role of metal oxide supports. The use of Al2O3 and FCC resulted in a lower thermo-oxidative stability of coke formed on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/FCC compared to Ni/Char. Furthermore, the deposited Ni showed higher stability towards oxidation by steam into NiO in case of Al2O3 and FCC compared to char. According to reforming activity, H2 production rate, coking, and Ni oxidation of the catalysts, FCC has better prospects as an alternative support in a reforming catalyst than char.
